choices.text: 100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid OD
100 mg elemental iron + 250 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid daily

questions.text: The WHO recommendation for universal iron supplementation to pregnant woman includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 60 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid daily

  • The WHO recommends universal iron supplementation to all pregnant women with 30-60 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid once daily for 6 months starting as early as possible
  • For treatment of anemia, 120 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid is given.

Suggested scheme for daily iron and folic acid supplementation in pregnant women by the WHO

* Remember what has been asked is the WHO recommendation and not the Anemia Mukt Bharat recommendation which is single tablet containing 60mg elemental iron + 500 mcg of folic acid, starting from 14 weeks and given for 180 days in pregnancy, continued for 180 days in lactation

 

Educational Objective:

Suggested scheme for daily iron and folic acid supplementation in pregnant women by the WHO

Reference - https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/77770/9789241501996_eng.pdf

choices.text: Tab Albendazole 400 mg in the 1st trimester
Tab Albendazole 400 mg in the 2nd trimester
Tab Albendazole 400mg in the 3rd trimester
Tab Albendazole 400mg in any trimester

questions.text: The Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy comprises 6 strategies to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India. One of these is deworming of pregnant women. Deworming of pregnant women is ideally done by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tab Albendazole 400 mg in the 2nd trimester

  • As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat program
    • Pregnant women and lactating mothers are advised one dose of 400 mg Albendazole (1 tablet), after the first trimester, preferably during the second trimester.
    • Women of reproductive age group (20 – 49) – not pregnant and not lactating: Biannual dose of 400 mg Albendazole.

Educational Objective:

  • As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat program
    • Pregnant women and lactating mothers are advised one dose of 400 mg Albendazole (1 tablet), after the first trimester, preferably during the second trimester.
    • Women of reproductive age group (20 – 49) – not pregnant and not lactating: Biannual dose of 400 mg Albendazole.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 12 weeks for a booking visit. On routine testing, her Hb is 9g%. As per the center for Disease Control, the definition of anemia in pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. < 11g% in the 1st and 3rd trimester and < 10.5g% in the 2nd trimester

  • As per the CDC, the definition of anemia in pregnancy is < 11g% in the 1st and 3rd trimesters and < 10.5g% in the 2nd trimester
  • As per the WHO, Anemia in pregnancy is defined as Hb < 11g%
  • The severity is further classified based on the Hb as given below

Educational Objective:

  • As per the CDC, the definition of anemia in pregnancy is < 11g% in the 1st and 3rd trimesters and < 10.5g% in the 2nd trimester
  • As per the WHO, Anemia in pregnancy is defined as Hb < 11g%

Ref: page no 245, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Calcium
Helminthiasis
Multiple pregnancies at short intervals
Alcohol consumption

questions.text: All of the following increases the prevalence of iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Alcohol consumption

Let's Discuss all the Options

  • Option A: Calcium: Reduces iron absorption in the body. That is why calcium and iron supplements are taken at different times
  • Option B: Helmnithiasis: This reduces the iron absorption in the body
  • Option C: Multple pregnancies at short intervals: This reduces the iron stores in the body as there is an increased demand. 
  • Option D: Alcohol: Alcohol increases iron absorption in the body

Educational Objective: 

Factors affecting iron stores in the body

 

*Alcohol  increases iron absorption in the body

Ref:  Page no 484, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1st edition

choices.text: Congenital anomalies
Preeclampsia
Postpartum haemorrhage
Fetal growth restriction

questions.text: A 32y G4 presents at 12 weeks. She appears pale and her Hb is 6g%. You explain to her she is at risk of all the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Congenital anomalies

  • Congenital anomalies are not associated with anemia in pregnancy

Educational Objective:

Ref:  Page no 485, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1st edition

choices.text: Test for thalassemia
Blood transfusion
Parenteral iron
Oral ferrous fumarate

questions.text: A 22-year primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD at 18 weeks with anemia. Her Hb is 7.2g%. The MCV is 73 µ3 and MCH is 25 pg. The TIBC is 420 µg/ 100 ml & serum ferritin is 15 mg/ ml. She has been intolerant to ferrous sulfate which was prescribed at 14 weeks. What will you advise her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Parenteral iron

  • This is a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia (microcytic hypochromic with reduced iron stores and raised TIBC)
  • Since she is intolerant to oral iron and she has moderate anemia, parenteral iron therapy is advised

Let's Discuss the Other options

  • Option A: Test for Thalassemia: The picture given here is more likely iron deficiency anemia as the TIBC is raised and ferritin is low
  • Option B: Blood transfusion: This is not recommeded for this patient. Blood transfusion in iron deficiency anemia is recommended ins evere anemia at or near term
  • Option C: Parenteral iron: This is the best option for this patient as she has moderate iron deficiency anemia, is far from term and is intolerable to oral iron
  • Option D: Oral ferrous fumerate: Changing the formulation of oral iron usually does not help and as per anemia mukt bharat, the next best option would be to administer parenteral iron

Educational Objective:

Indications of parenteral iron therapy in pregnancy

Ref: Page no 484 - 488, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1st edition

choices.text: 2008
2010
2015
2018

questions.text: The Anemia Mukt Bharat to reduce the prevalence of anemia was launched in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2018

  • Considering, the slow progress i.e., less than 1% per annum in reduction of anaemia from 2005 to 2015, the Government of India has launched the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy under the Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan and the targets has been set to reduce anaemia by 3% per year

 

  • This program has a 6x6x6 strategy under AMB i.e.
    • Six age groups
    • Six interventions and
    • Six institutional mechanisms

 

  • The six population groups under AMB strategy are:
    • Children (6-59 months)
    • Children (5-9 years)
    • Adolescent girls and boys (10-19 years)
    • Pregnant women
    • Lactating women (till the infant is 6 months old)
    • Women of Reproductive Age (WRA) group (15-49 years)
  • The six interventions are:
  • Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation
  • Deworming
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) Campaign and delayed cord clamping
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point of care treatment,
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in Government funded health programmes
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies and fluorosis
  • The six institutional mechanisms are:
  • Inter-ministerial coordination
  • National Anemia Mukt Bharat Unit
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced research on Anemia Control
  • Convergence with other ministries
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics
  • Anemia Mukt Bharat Dashboard and Digital Portal- one-stop shop for Anemia.

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Government of India has launched the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy in 2018 under the Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan and the targets has been set to reduce anaemia by 3% per year
  • This program has a 6x6x6 strategy under AMB i.e.
    • Six age groups
    • Six interventions and
    • Six institutional mechanisms

Ref: https://pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=1596308

choices.text: Rise in Hct
Rise in Hb level
Reticulocytosis
Increase in TIBC

questions.text: A 20 y G1 is on treatment for iron deficiency anemia with oral iron which was started at 24 weeks. She visits the antenatal OPD after 1 week. The earliest evidence of response to therapy is.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Reticulocytosis

Response of therapy to oral iron in iron deficiency anemia is evidenced by

  • Sense of well being
  • Increased appetite
  • Rise in Hb levels
  • Hematocrit value returning to normal.
  • Reticulocytosis within 7 - 10 days (earliest sign)

Educational Objective:

 

Response of therapy to oral iron in iron deficiency anemia is evidenced by

  • Sense of well being
  • Increased appetite
  • Rise in Hb levels
  • Hematocrit value returning to normal.
  • Reticulocytosis within 7 - 10 days (earliest sign)

Ref: Page no 250, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Ferrous fumarate 200 mg/ day
Folic acid 5 mg/ day
Iron carboxymaltose 1000 mg IV
Blood transfusion

questions.text: A 32 y G4P2 presented at 20 weeks with a Hb of 8.7g%. On evaluation, the peripheral smear is as shown below. What would the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folic acid 5mg/ day

  • The peripheral blood smear is showing hypersegmented neutrophils which is classically seen in megaloblastic anemia
  • A common cause of megaloblastic anemia in pregnancy is folate deficiency.
  • Folate deficiency presents as
    • Hb < 11 g%
    • MCV > 96 fl, MCH > 33
    • Peripheral blood smear shows megaloblastic anemia with normochromia with hypersegmented neutrophils, anisocytosis, giant polymorphs, megaloblasts and Howell Jolley bodies.
    • Anisocytosis
    • Los serum folate levels (< 3 ng/ ml)
  • Treatment of folate deficiency is by
    • Folic acid 4mg (or 5 mg)/ day; continued for at least 4 weeks following delivery
    • Supplemental iron therapy should be given in cases of suspected dimorphic anemia

Let's Discuss the other options 

  • Option A: Ferrous fumarate: This is given in iron deficiency which is not the case in this patient. However nutritional anemias coexist and if iron deficiency also exists, oral iron needs to be supplemented
  • Option C: Iron carboxymaltose 1000 mg IV: This is parenterla iron which is inidcated when there is non compliance or intolerance to oral iron
  • Option D: Blood transfusion: This is indicated in severe anemia at or near term

Ref: Page no 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Cut short the 2nd stage with forceps.
Cut short the 2nd stage with vacuum
Avoid episiotomy
IV fluids to avoid dehydration

questions.text: A 20 y G2P1 presents at 36 weeks in labor. On examination she has pallor. Her PR is 90/min and BP is 110/70 mmHg. Her Hb is 4g%. Which of the following should be done in the 2nd stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cut short the 2nd stage with forceps.

  • This patient has 2 complications: Severe anemia and preterm labor
  • Management of severe anemia in labor
    • 1st stage of labor
      • Sedation; lie in left lateral position
      • Pain relief
      • Oxygen ready
      • Antibiotic prophylaxis after membrane rupture
      • Avoid overloading with Intravenous fluids; encourage oral hydration
      • Strict asepsis
      • Arrange and transfuse packed cells if required
    • 2nd stage of labor
      • Cut short with forceps (Especially in this scenario as she is preterm – vacuum is contraindicated in preterm. Also, forceps is preferred in scenarios where the woman should not bear down as vacuum requires additional bearing down efforts).
    • 3rd stage
      • Active management of 3rd stage of labor
      • Avoid methylergometrine in very severe anemia/ patient in failure

Educational Objective:

 

  • Precuation to be taken in 2nd stage of labor in a patient with severe anemia
    • Cut short with forceps (Especially in this scenario as she is preterm – vacuum is contraindicated in preterm. Also, forceps is preferred in scenarios where the woman should not bear down as vacuum requires additional bearing down efforts).

Ref: Page no 251, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Platelet count is usually > 70000/ mm3
Usually occurs in the 1st trimester.
Resolves in the postpartum period
May recur in the next pregnancy

questions.text: All are true regarding gestational thrombocytopenia except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Usually occurs in the 1st trimester

Gestational thrombocytopenia is seen in the 2nd/ 3rd trimester

Gestational thrombocytopenia

  • Affects about 5 – 10% of all pregnancies
  • Thrombocytopenia is mild (platelet count is usually > 70000/ mm3)
  • Occurs in the late 2nd/ 3rd trimester
  • It occurs due to physiological changes in pregnancy i.e., increased blood volume and increased platelet destruction
  • Resolves postpartum and is a diagnosis of exclusion
  • Does not affect the fetus/ neonate
  • May recur in subsequent pregnancies

Educational Objective:

Gestational thrombocytopenia

  • Affects about 5 – 10% of all pregnancies
  • Thrombocytopenia is mild (platelet count is usually > 70000/ mm3)
  • Occurs in the late 2nd/ 3rd trimester
  • It occurs due to physiological changes in pregnancy i.e., increased blood volume and increased platelet destruction
  • Resolves postpartum and is a diagnosis of exclusion
  • Does not affect the fetus/ neonate
  • May recur in subsequent pregnancies

Ref: Page no 256, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

questions.text: The total amount of iron in pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1000 mg

  • The total amount of iron required in pregnancy is 1000 mg i.e., 4 – 6 mg/ day
  • This can be broken up as

 

 

 

 

 

  • Amount of iron saved due to amenorrhea: 300 mg
  • So total requirement in pregnancy = 1200 – 300 = 900 mg (Approx 1000mg)

Educational Objective:

Iron Requirement in Pregnancy:

 

 

 

 

Ref: Page no 55, Textbook of Obstetrics by DC Dutta 9th edition

questions.text: A 20y primigravida presents in the 1st trimester for a routine antenatal visit. She is counseled regarding dietary advice. The average requirement of iron in pregnancy per day is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 4mg/day

  • The average iron requirement in pregnancy is 4 mg/ day
  • Iron requirement is less in early pregnancy (2.5 mg/day) and more after 32 weeks (6 – 8mg/day)
  • Iron absorption is < 10%, hence 40 – 60 mg or dietary iron is required.

Educational Objective:

  • The average iron requirement in pregnancy is 4 mg/ day

Ref: Page no 484, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1st edition

1 iron and folic acid tablet (containing 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) from the 2nd trimester continued throughout pregnancy and 180 days postpartum.
1 iron and folic acid tablet (containing 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) from the 2nd trimester continued throughout pregnancy and 42 days postpartum.

questions.text: The Anemia Mukt Bharat program recommends which of the following for prophylaxis in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1 iron and folic acid tablet (containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) from the 2nd trimester continued throughout pregnancy and 180 days postpartum.

As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat, the following is recommended for prophylaxis in pregnant and lactating women:

  • Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet.
  • Starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester)
  • Continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy)
  • To be continued for 180 days, post-partum
  • Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid
  • Each tablet is sugar-coated and red in colour.

Educational Objective: 

 

As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat, the following is recommended for prophylaxis in pregnant and lactating women:

  • Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet.
  • Starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester)
  • Continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy)
  • To be continued for 180 days, post-partum
  • Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid
  • Each tablet is sugar-coated and red in colour.

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/home/interventions/

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy to reduce the prevalence of anemia, the color of the iron and folic acid tablets given to the adolescent age group are:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Blue

Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme, different beneficiaries get different iron/ folic acid supplementation -

Children aged 6-59 months:

  1.  Biweekly, 1 ml Iron and Folic Acid syrup
  2. Each ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental Iron + 100 mcg of Folic Acid
  3. Bottle (50ml) to have an ‘auto-dispenser’

Children 5-9 years

  • Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet
  • Each tablet containing 45 mg elemental Iron + 400 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, pink colour.

Adolescent (10-19 years)

  • Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, blue colour.

Women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating) 20–49 years

  • Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, red colour.

Pregnant women and lactating mothers (of 0–6 months child)

  • Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester), continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy)
  • To be continued for 180 days, post-partum
  • Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, red colour

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme, different beneficiaries get different iron/ folic acid supplementation -

Children aged 6-59 months:

  1.  Biweekly, 1 ml Iron and Folic Acid syrup
  2. Each ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental Iron + 100 mcg of Folic Acid
  3. Bottle (50ml) to have an ‘auto-dispenser’

Children 5-9 years

  • Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet
  • Each tablet containing 45 mg elemental Iron + 400 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, pink colour.

Adolescent (10-19 years)

  • Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, blue colour.

Women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating) 20–49 years

  • Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, red colour.

Pregnant women and lactating mothers (of 0–6 months child)

  • Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester), continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy)
  • To be continued for 180 days, post-partum
  • Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, sugar-coated, red colour

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/home/interventions/

75%

questions.text: A couple went for pre-conceptional counseling and was detected to be anemic. On investigation, they were both found to have beta thalassemia minor. The chance their fetus will have thalassemia major is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 25%

  • Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced
  • If the mother has thalassemia trait (beta thalassemia minor), the father’s status is checked.
  • If the father also has the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% (1 in 4 chance) the fetus has beta thalassemia major.
  • Prenatal diagnosis is done by
    • Chorionic villous sampling in the 1st trimester OR
    • Amniocentesis in the 2nd trimester

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced
  • If the mother has thalassemia trait (beta thalassemia minor), the father’s status is checked.
  • If the father also has the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% (1 in 4 chance) the fetus has beta thalassemia major.
  • Prenatal diagnosis is done by
    • Chorionic villous sampling in the 1st trimester OR
    • Amniocentesis in the 2nd trimester

Ref: Page no 494, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1st edition

choices.text: Amniocentesis
Chorionic villous sampling
Cordocentesis
Medical termination of Pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida at 8 weeks is found to have mild anemia. On evaluation, she is detected to be beta thalassemia minor. Her husband is also found to have the thalassemia trait. What investigation would you advise her next?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chorionic villous sampling

  • Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced
  • If the mother has thalassemia trait (beta thalassemia minor), the father’s status is checked.
  • If the father also has the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% (1 in 4 chance) the fetus has beta thalassemia major.
  • Prenatal diagnosis is done by
    • Chorionic villous sampling (CVS) in the 1st trimester OR
    • Amniocentesis in the 2nd trimester

 

** As this patient has reported early at 6 weeks, a CVS would be the best option as it would lead to earlier reporting and if required (i.e., if the fetus is beta thalassemia major), termination of pregnancy would be easier at a lower gestational age.

Educational Objective:

  • Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced
  • If the mother has thalassemia trait (beta thalassemia minor), the father’s status is checked.
  • If the father also has the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% (1 in 4 chance) the fetus has beta thalassemia major.
  • Prenatal diagnosis is done by
    • Chorionic villous sampling (CVS) in the 1st trimester OR
    • Amniocentesis in the 2nd trimester

Ref: Page no 494, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1st edition

choices.text: Peripheral blood smear
Serum ferritin
Serum iron levels
Total iron binding capacity

questions.text: The single best test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Serum ferritin

  • The single best test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia is serum ferritin
  • Serum ferritin is a high molecular weight glycoprotein
  • Normal concentration is 15 – 300 mcg/ L
  • It is the single indicator of iron deficiency
  • Levels < 30 mcg/ L show iron deficiency anemia with a 90% sensitivity and a 85% specificity
  • It is unaffected by recent iron intake and is the first abnormal laboratory test in iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

 

  • The single best test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia is serum ferritin
  • Serum ferritin is a high molecular weight glycoprotein
  • Normal concentration is 15 – 300 mcg/ L
  • It is the single indicator of iron deficiency
  • Levels < 30 mcg/ L show iron deficiency anemia with a 90% sensitivity and a 85% specificity
  • It is unaffected by recent iron intake and is the first abnormal laboratory test in iron deficiency anemia

Reference - Page no 486, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1st edition

choices.text: Low serum ferritin
Increased transferrin saturation
Raised TIBC
High Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin

questions.text: A 29 y G3P2 presents to the antenatal OPD with severe anemia. On evaluation, she is found to have iron deficiency anemia. Which will not be seen in her investigations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increased transferrin saturation

Iron deficiency anemia is common in pregnancy; It is characterized by the following reports:

  1. Reduced MCV, MCH and MCHC
  2. Low serum iron
  3. Low serum ferritin (1st test to be abnormal)
  4. Low transferrin saturation (10% or less)
  5. Raised free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP > 50)
  6. Raised Total iron binding capacity (TIBC)
  7. Raised serum transferrin receptor levels.

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is common in pregnancy; It is characterized by the following reports:

  1. Reduced MCV, MCH and MCHC
  2. Low serum iron
  3. Low serum ferritin (1st test to be abnormal)
  4. Low transferrin saturation (10% or less)
  5. Raised free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP > 50)
  6. Raised Total iron binding capacity (TIBC)
  7. Raised serum transferrin receptor levels.

Ref: Page no 486, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1st edition

choices.text: Iron sucrose and Iron Dextran
Iron Sucrose
Iron Sucrose and iron Carboxymaltose
Iron Carboxymaltose

questions.text: A 34y G2 is diagnosed to have anemia during her routine prenatal visits. She is started on oral iron but is unable to tolerate it. As per Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, which parenteral preparations of iron is recommended for treatment of iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Iron Sucrose and Iron Carboxymaltose

As per Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, the following is recommended as first line strategy for treatment of anemia

  1. For mild anemia (10 – 10.9 g%)
    • Two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid tablet (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by the health provider during the ANC contact.
    • Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up)
    • Follow up every 2 monthly
    • Once Hb is at the normal level, continue with prophylactic dose
  2. For moderate anemia (7 – 9.9 g%)
    • Two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid tablet (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by the health provider during the ANC contact
    • Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up)
    • If no improvement in haemoglobin (<1 g/dl increase) after two months of treatment, refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) by health provider
  3. For severe anemia (5 – 6.9 g%)
    • Management of severe anemia in pregnant women will be done by the medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH
    • The treatment will be done using IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) by the medical officer
    • Immediate hospitalization recommended in the third trimester of pregnancy at a health facility where round-the-clock specialist care is available

Educational Objective:

 

As per Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, the following is recommended as first line strategy for treatment of anemia

  1. For mild anemia (10 – 10.9 g%)
    • Two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid tablet (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by the health provider during the ANC contact.
    • Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up)
    • Follow up every 2 monthly
    • Once Hb is at the normal level, continue with prophylactic dose
  2. For moderate anemia (7 – 9.9 g%)
    • Two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid tablet (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by the health provider during the ANC contact
    • Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up)
    • If no improvement in haemoglobin (<1 g/dl increase) after two months of treatment, refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) by health provider
  3. For severe anemia (5 – 6.9 g%)
    • Management of severe anemia in pregnant women will be done by the medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH
    • The treatment will be done using IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) by the medical officer
    • Immediate hospitalization recommended in the third trimester of pregnancy at a health facility where round-the-clock specialist care is available

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/home/interventions/

choices.text: α Thalassemia Major
α Thalassemia Minor
β Thalassemia Major
β Thalassemia Minor

questions.text: Which of the following thalassemia syndromes in the fetus presents as hydrops?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. α Thalassemia Major

  • Alpha chain defects:
    • Bart’s Hb: All 4 alpha globin chains are defective with no alpha chain production. This results in 4 gamma chains. The fetus is hydropic and incompatible with life.
    • In alpha thalassemia trait: there is 1 defective gene
    • In alpha thalassemia minor: there are 2 defective genes
    • In HbH disease, there are 3 defective genes and the patient has moderate hemolytic anemia
  • Beta chain defects
    • Beta thalassemia major (Coole’s anemia): Both beta globin genes are defective and no beta chains are produced; individuals are transfusion dependent throughout life
    • Beta thalassemia trait (minor): one beta globin gene is defective: mild anemia

 

Ref: Page no 492, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1st edition

choices.text: Fetal growth restriction
Preterm labor
Pre-eclampsia
Placenta previa

questions.text: All are effects of sickle cell disease on pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Placenta previa

Effects of sickle cell disease on pregnancy

  • Increased incidence of abortion
  • Preterm labor
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Fetal demise
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Postpartum haemorrhage
  • Infections

Effect of pregnancy on the disease

  • Hemolytic crisis
  • Painful (vaso-occlusive) crisis

Placenta previa is NOT seen in sicle cell anemia in pregnancy

Educational Objective:

 

Effects of sickle cell disease on pregnancy

  • Increased incidence of abortion
  • Preterm labor
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Fetal demise
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Postpartum haemorrhage
  • Infections

Effect of pregnancy on the disease

  • Hemolytic crisis
  • Painful (vaso-occlusive) crisis

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
Megaloblastic anemia
Sickle cell anemia
Thalassemia

questions.text: The most common anemia in pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iron deficiency anemia

  • Nutritional anemias are the most common type of anemias
  • Iron deficiency anemia is the most common nutritional anemia in pregnancy

Ref: Page no 250, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition
